headline: Two endangered incumbents admit Biden's America is bad in tv campaign ads
author: Karen Townsend
sentences: Mark Kelly in Arizona and Raphael Warnock in Georgia are walking a tightrope as they try to show empathy for everyday working Americans struggling in Biden’s economy while trying to assure them that Democrats have solutions for their problems.

The public has totally soured on Biden, tracing directly back to the botched withdrawal from Afghanistan, and Biden will not recover before the November midterm elections, barring any unforeseen events.
Warnock’s opponent, Trump-endorsed Republican frontrunner Herschel Walker sent a message to donors that Warnock paid $725,000 from his $23M campaign war chest to finance the ad.
The four most vulnerable Democrats in the Senate are Kelly, Warnock, Catherine Cortez Masto of Nevada, and Maggie Hassan of New Hampshire.
There is a red wave coming because of Biden’s incompetence in office and that wave will likely turn into a red tsunami.
Warnock reminds voters that he’s a pastor while he acknowledges that overnight families can see their lives upended.
Their four states are battleground states in the battle for control of the Senate in the November midterm elections.
Kelly’s approach is to use his own family’s story to talk about the struggles of those living paycheck to paycheck.
A few cents here and there in temporary gas tax relief is quickly replaced with higher gas prices for motorists.
They hope to convince Americans that it will bring down the price of gas for them at the pump but it will not.
Two of the most vulnerable Democrat incumbents in the Senate are running campaign ads very similar in message.
Kelly keeps his head down, rarely gets noticed, but he also is a reliable Democrat vote in the Senate.
As of today, Real Clear Politics has Walker up a point over Warnock and calls the race a toss-up.
And, he acknowledges that we no longer even know what normal is, much less how to get back to it.
Unfortunately for them, though, while they both try to forget Biden in their ads, voters cannot.
The best the vulnerable Democrats have come up with in the Senate is the Gas Prices Relief Act.
But $725,000 out of a $23M war chest seems like small potatoes for a statewide tv ad, right?
Biden’s poll numbers are in the dumpster and he’s bringing other Democrats down with him.
It isn’t looking like they have the stomach to trust Democrats in the midterm elections.
They admit that things are bad in Biden’s America without actually saying those words.
There is never any doubt with where Warnock stands and its with the progressive wing.
Walker said that expenditure shows Warnock is concerned about his reelection chances.

This is Raphael Warnock’s tv ad:
The messages from both are clear from the top.
Biden’s big transformation of America fever dream isn’t playing well anywhere.
Politicians have tried it in the past and it is a temporary relief at best.
It’s like a sugar high – it feels good briefly then the crash comes.
He’s also not seen as reliably progressive as Warnock is to voters.
Since then, Independents and suburban voters have abandoned Biden.
Biden won all four battleground states but they were small wins.
Mark Kelly stands a pretty good chance of being reelected.
Both tv ads are a smart way to go for the two candidates.
However, yes, Walker is right – Warnock sees the polls.
Kelly’s ad will run in the Phoenix and Tucson markets.
He’s consistently up over any of his GOP challengers.
Today, Mark Kelly released his first tv ad.
Things are tough but they feel your pain.
Neither utter the name of Joe Biden.
There is no avoiding that.
It will air statewide.
Good luck with that.
Nor should they.
